Bilingual children transfer pragmatic derivation of plural from bivalent to trivalent language system
Matic Pavliƒç, Arthur Stepanov, Penka Stateva
March 2023
 

The principles of pragmatic computation are universal and at first sight do not allow negative transfer, i.e. assigning values to linguistic features in one language according to their equivalent in another language. However, the triggers of pragmatic computation do not necessarily have the same properties in all languages, as their meaning is enriched in the context of the available alternatives in a language. Al Moussaoui and Stateva (2021) have shown that cross-linguistically different sets of alternatives lead to pragmatic negative transfer in L2 learning, while in this paper we investigate whether pragmatic negative transfer also characterises language acquisition. In a sentence-picture verification task, we analysed a language pair representing a bivalent (Italian) and a trivalent (Slovene) morphological number system of nouns and confirmed negative transfer in balanced early bilingual children.
